definition: serve Qin in the morning Chu in the evening (idiom); quick to switch sides
abbr. for 朝鮮|朝鲜[Chao2 xian3] Korea
imperial or royal court/government/dynasty/reign of a sovereign or emperor/court or assembly held by a sovereign or emperor/to make a pilgrimage to/facing/towards
morning
surname Qin/Qin dynasty (221-207 BC) of the first emperor 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]/abbr. for 陝西|陕西[Shan3 xi1]
evening/sunset
distinct/clear/orderly/pain/suffering/deciduous bush used in Chinese medicine (genus Vitex)/punishment cane (old)
surname Chu/abbr. for Hubei 湖北省[Hu2 bei3 Sheng3] and Hunan 湖南省[Hu2 nan2 Sheng3] provinces together/Chinese kingdom during the Spring and Autumn and Warring States Periods (722-221 BC)

sentences.english: His rivals often mock him for flip- flopping.
sentences.chinese: 他的對手經常模仿他的朝秦暮楚。

definition: lit. say three in the morning but four in the evening (idiom); to change sth that is already settled upon/indecisive/to blow hot and cold

lit. covet Sichuan once Gansu has been seized/fig. endless greed/insatiable desire
unstable/erratic/changeable/fickle
two-faced, three knives (idiom); double-cross/double dealing and back stabbing
indecisive/irresolute
to see profit and forget morality (idiom); to act from mercenary considerations/to sell one's soul for gain
fickle (woman)
to be shortsighted
sb who goes whichever way the wind blows/sb with no mind of their own/easily swayed person/opportunist
to curry favor (idiom); playing up to those in power/social climbing
lit. eyeing what's in the pot as one eats from one's bowl (idiom)/not content with what one already has/(of men, typically) to have the wandering eye

definition: lit. see the wind and set the helm (idiom); fig. to act pragmatically/to be flexible and take advantage of the situation
